articles.headline: In Sync to Pierce the Cloud
articles.snippet: Apple overhauls its .Mac service and calls it MobileMe, an effort to synchronize in real time all of the data on all of your computers.
articles.abstract: Apple overhauls its .Mac service and calls it MobileMe, an effort to synchronize in real time all of the data on all of your computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Cloud computing” is a white-hot buzzword these days. It basically means working with files and programs that reside on the Internet, beyond your company’s walls — out there in the “cloud.”

articles.headline: Shares Revive Amid Confusing Signs From S.E.C.
articles.snippet: Euphoria tinged with a bit of panic swept Wall Street on Wednesday, as battered financial shares roared back in their biggest one-day rally ever.
articles.abstract: Euphoria tinged with a bit of panic swept Wall Street on Wednesday, as battered financial shares roared back in their biggest one-day rally ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Euphoria tinged with a bit of panic swept Wall Street on Wednesday, as battered financial shares roared back in their biggest one-day rally ever.

articles.headline: Remember ‘2 All-Beef Patties?’ McDonald’s Hopes You Do
articles.snippet: McDonald’s is sponsoring a song-contest using the jingle on MySpace. The official reason is the 40th anniversary of the Big Mac, but the then-and-now similarities are not entirely lost on the company.
articles.abstract: McDonald’s is sponsoring a song-contest using the jingle on MySpace. The official reason is the 40th anniversary of the Big Mac, but the then-and-now similarities are not entirely lost on the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The year was 1974: gas prices were high, inflation was rampant and an unpopular Republican occupied the White House. McDonald’s introduced a spirit-lifting jingle: “Two all beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions, on a sesame-seed bun.”

articles.headline: Prisoners’ Homecoming a Triumph for Hezbollah
articles.snippet: In a large celebration of the release of five prisoners from Israel, Hezbollah sought to rally Lebanon behind its yellow flag.
articles.abstract: In a large celebration of the release of five prisoners from Israel, Hezbollah sought to rally Lebanon behind its yellow flag.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of people waving flags, lighting fireworks, smiling, laughing, and jostling for a view of Hezbollah’s leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, packed into an open square in this city’s southern suburb on Wednesday night to celebrate the release of five prisoners from Israel. A banner strung over the crowd read: “God’s Achievement Through Our Hands.”

articles.headline: In Iraq, Mixed Feelings About Obama and His Troop Proposal
articles.snippet: There is excitement in Iraq about Barack Obama, who is preparing to visit the country, but his support for the withdrawal of U.S. troops cuts both ways.
articles.abstract: There is excitement in Iraq about Barack Obama, who is preparing to visit the country, but his support for the withdrawal of U.S. troops cuts both ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A tough Iraqi general, a former special operations officer with a baritone voice and a barrel chest, melted into smiles when asked about Senator Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Menthol Dose Manipulated, Study Says
articles.snippet: A Harvard study claims the tobacco industry in recent years has manipulated menthol levels to appeal to younger smokers.
articles.abstract: A Harvard study claims the tobacco industry in recent years has manipulated menthol levels to appeal to younger smokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new Harvard study claims that the tobacco industry in recent years has manipulated menthol levels in cigarettes to hook youngsters and maintain loyalty among smoking adults. The report could further inflame a controversy over menthol in pending tobacco legislation.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Expected to Buy Merrill’s Stake in His Firm
articles.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and one of his earliest business partners are parting company in a deal that places a public value of the mayor’s private company. That figure: At least $22.5 billion.
articles.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and one of his earliest business partners are parting company in a deal that places a public value of the mayor’s private company. That figure: At least $22.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than two decades, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and one of his earliest business partners, Merrill Lynch, are parting company in a deal that places a public value on the mayor’s private company, Bloomberg L.P.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Louise Story

articles.headline: Economic Fears Slice Oil Prices for Second Day
articles.snippet: Concerns about an economic slowdown pushed oil down yet again, prompting a 2.5 percent jump in the Dow, amid new evidence of rising prices.
articles.abstract: Concerns about an economic slowdown pushed oil down yet again, prompting a 2.5 percent jump in the Dow, amid new evidence of rising prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Concerns about a slowing economy and rising inflation pushed oil prices down sharply for a second day on Wednesday, an unusual dip in the oil price rally that began more than six years ago.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Problems Persist With Red Cross Blood Services
articles.snippet: Despite $21 million in fines and repeated vows to improve its methods, the American Red Cross is still falling short.
articles.abstract: Despite $21 million in fines and repeated vows to improve its methods, the American Red Cross is still falling short.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 15 years, the American Red Cross has been under a federal court order to improve the way it collects and processes blood. Yet, despite $21 million in fines since 2003 and repeated promises to follow procedures intended to ensure the safety of the nation’s blood supply, it continues to fall short.

articles.headline: The Wild Green Yonder
articles.snippet: Airplane manufacturers are trying to bolster their green credentials by lauding initiatives to reduce the environmental impact of flying, as well as the cost.
articles.abstract: Airplane manufacturers are trying to bolster their green credentials by lauding initiatives to reduce the environmental impact of flying, as well as the cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARNBOROUGH, England  The air show here can often feel like aviation’s World Cup, with makers of jet fighters, commercial aircraft, helicopters and private planes from around the globe vying for bigger-faster-stronger bragging rights.

articles.headline: Car Buyers Downsize, but Spend Big on Options
articles.snippet: People of all income levels are buying small cars but they are not scrimping on creature comforts.
articles.abstract: People of all income levels are buying small cars but they are not scrimping on creature comforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Consumers used to buy small cars for a simple reason: they were cheap. A decade ago, many budget-minded shoppers turned down even options like air-conditioning, power windows and compact disc players to keep the price low.
